text:
Are there any amazing “resource hub” sections you’ve come across in SaaS-land that you were reeeally digging? Mainly looking for *downloadable* resource hubs (i.e. playbooks, reports, webinars, etc.), not just blog content.

*Obvious example to start from --->* <https://www.hubspot.com/resources|Hubspot>

…. But I’m trying to go beyond just them. Any coming to mind?

text: <@URAV154AV> I am wondering the same thing. My assumption is that if the company has an office, they will get mail to execs and VPs one way or another. Maybe direct mail is just dead!

elements.text: I am wondering the same thing. My assumption is that if the company has an office, they will get mail to execs and VPs one way or another. Maybe direct mail is just dead!

text:
Hey <@U02RT4NUGPK> - I work for a nonprofit and direct mail is alive and well! We do mailings all the time, but more so to 'warm' addresses.

You're on the right track with handwritten notes. We do *lots* of them and they tend to get a response. Plus, many times, a personal handwritten letter will get handed to the CEO directly vs. a letter that just has their name (because let's face it, every letter has the CEO's name and they don't have time for that!)

I wouldn't worry about them not being somewhere. We typically all get mail somewhere. And we forget that a large majority of people aren't remote or out galivanting the world.

I might consider putting something like your phone number or email on there, plus state that you will reach out to them again in 2 weeks or something like that.

text:
Lattice are doing are a great job with <https://lattice.com/library|their library>, especially after the latest redesign. They have all types of resources — eBooks, webinars, interviews, etc.

Also, <https://miro.com/guides/|Miro’s guide>s section is awesome in terms of content, design and overall feel, but I don’t think they have downloadable stuff.

text:
Hey all :wave:

I have been talking about B2B product-led content marketing** for a while (most recently… <https://contentfolks.substack.com/p/three-levels-of-product-content?|two days ago> :wink:) and I think of it as a potentially successful, but very under-utilised content marketing tactic.
And now I’m generally curious to know—is anybody here trying this approach in your work?
If yes → what results are you seeing? If no → why not?

**think of the blog posts & guides you may see on Ahrefs, SparkToro, Hotjar–these are all good examples of product-led content in my book.

text:
Core part of what I do for sure. Just need to get the design team to let me put more actual screenshots versus design-led mockups (which I love BTW) :joy:

Example: <https://www.activecampaign.com/email-marketing>

Example:

text:
Ah yes!, I was going to mention the part about illustrations :slightly_smiling_face:

To me, a crucial part of a product-led content piece is the fact that it shows the product (or service) in action [bonus points for doing it multiple times] so the audience can become familiar with what it looks like / can imagine themselves using it. I guess in your example there is at least one instance of that (the drag-and-drop designer) :slightly_smiling_face:

Are you seeing good long-term results with this approach?

text:
Yeah, I guess. I think being able to show gifs of the actual product is the most important part. Ahrefs was always best at this because their product isn't design-led and they have ZERO problem showing the dashboard a bajillion times in every article.

Customer transformation > How pretty the software is

text:
The best way I've found to get people to show up is to reduce the number of unqualified inbound leads that end up on the calendar to begin with. 

This major levers we pull to do this typically include:

1. Provide pricing up front on the site.
2. Make it more clear what you do and who you do it for. Jobs to be done. 
3. Make it more clear what you do not do and who you do not do it for.
4. Refine your distribution channels and targeting. Don’t write blog posts that don’t speak to the right audience. Don’t write generic social copy that’s too broad. Target audiences more surgically with advertising on LinkedIn or using Clearbit if on FB/IG/Google Ads.
5. Reduce the time between booking a call and having that call (much easier when you reduce the number of bad fit calls getting booked on the calendar by doing the above).

elements.text:
The best way I've found to get people to show up is to reduce the number of unqualified inbound leads that end up on the calendar to begin with. 

This major levers we pull to do this typically include:
Provide pricing up front on the site.
Make it more clear what you do and who you do it for. Jobs to be done.
Make it more clear what you do not do and who you do not do it for.

Refine your distribution channels and targeting. Don’t write blog posts that don’t speak to the right audience. Don’t write generic social copy that’s too broad. Target audiences more surgically with advertising on LinkedIn or using Clearbit if on FB/IG/Google Ads.
Reduce the time between booking a call and having that call (much easier when you reduce the number of bad fit calls getting booked on the calendar by doing the above).
Any input here
